title: Deadlock Modelling
helpContent:
How to create your graph

Create Process

Double Click

Create processes with a left double click on the canvas. You can create as much processes as you wish. After the letters of the alphabet run out they will repeat.

Create Resource

Ctrl + Double Click

Create as many resources as you want holdind ctrl and left double clicking. You can create as much resources as you wish.

Move Processes or Resources

Drag

Left click over a process or resource, hold and drag to move a process or resource.

Connect

Right Click Drag

Right click over a process, hold and drag to a resource to create a unidirectional connection from the process to the resource or right click over a resource, hold and drag to a process to create a unidirectional connection from the resource to the process.

Delete

Double Click

Double click over a process, resource or connection to delete it.

Deadlock

Red arrows

The connections between processes an resources that are in deadlock will turn red.
explanationContent:
A set of processes are deadlocked if each process in the set is waiting for an event that only another process in the set can generate. How all the processes are waiting, none of the them can generate the event the other process needs. All the processes remain stuck, therefore deadlocked. A deadlock occurs whenever the following four conditions are met:

  1. Mutual exclusion.
  2. Hold an wait.
  3. Non preeptive.
  4. Circular wait.

Richard C. Holt showed how these conditions can be modeled using directed graphs. This OER was developed based on his model.

The OER has two simulations, the 'Guided Simulation' and 'Free Simulation'. The Guided Simulation will teach how processes, resources, requests and ownerships are represented in the model, and show examples step by step how deadlocks may or may not occur. The Free Simulation will allow the user to create his own states and see if a deadlock will occur

instruction.2: Edges from processes to resources are requests for resources by processes
instruction.3: Edges from resources to processes are ownerships of resources by processes
instruction.4: Now imagine a situation with three processes and three resources
instruction.9: A requests 2, notice A has to wait for B to release 2
instruction.10: B requests 3, notice how A and B have to wait for another process
instruction.11: C requests 1, closing a cycle. Every process in it is waiting for a resource held by another inside the cycle, that makes a deadlock
instruction.12: In concurrent programming, the order of requests is very important. Look at what would happen if requests were made on a different order
instruction.17: B requests 2, but B must wait for A to release 2
instruction.18: A owns all the resources it needs, so it uses and releases them
instruction.22: B owns all the resources it needs, so it uses and releases them
instruction.24: C owns 3, released by B, and 1 released by A
instruction.25: C owns all the resources it needs, so it uses and releases them
instruction.26: In this case no deadlock occurred due to the order of the ownerships attribution.
